questions.text: A 25-year-old man arrives at the emergency department after undergoing the physical fitness test for army job. He had to lift a 50 kg bag, run up a flight of stairs while carrying it, and proceed across a balance beam. He then had to do 50 pushups and 50 sit-ups. At the end, he developed dark urine and diffuse muscle pain. On examination BP: 112/70 mm Hg; P: 108 beats/minute; Temperature: 98°F; weak, tired, and in pain. Heart, Lung, Abdomen: normal, Reports: ECG: peaked T waves, potassium 6.8 mEq/dL; BUN 26 g/dL; creatinine 1.5 mg/dL, urine dipstick + blood, Calcium level: 6.8 mg/dL (low) Phosphate:7.0 mg/dl(elevated).What will be the immediate next step in the management

A 34-year-old man comes to OPD after noticing what he thinks is blood in his urine off and on for the past few months. The first time he had it, his other physician gave him an antibiotic. Now it has recurred. He has a sore throat the day before each episode. BP:143/92 mm Hg; Temperature: 98°F.Urine routine: RBCs 100 to 200, dysmorphic RBC, No white cells, No protein. Which of the following can be the cause of hematuria

In continuation with the patient in previous question, you further investigate. Urine culture-sterile, Ultrasound: normal; no stones; no hydronephrosis; no cysts. Repeat urine routine shows the findings as shown in the figure.

A 36-year-old man comes to see you at your OPD for swelling of both of his legs developing slowly over several months. He has seen another physician who gave him a diuretic to decrease the swelling, but there was no improvement. Past medical history: Hyperlipidemia for 2 years on atorvastatin. On examination-BP: 110/70 mm Hg; P: 80 beats/minute. Chest: clear to auscultation, Cardiovascular: no murmurs, no gallops Extremities: bilateral lower extremity edema, mild periorbital edema. Urinalysis: 4+ protein, oval fat bodies, Echocardiogram: normal, serum albumin 2.1 g/dL, Liver function tests: normal,serum Low-density lipoprotein (LDL) 145 mg/dL; triglycerides 500 mg/dL (elevated).What is the likely cause of this patient presentation.

A 35 year old male was diagnosed to have focal segmental glomerulosclerosis on kidney biopsy in view of anasarca, low serum albumin and massive proteinuria.There is no past medical history of diabetes,sickle cell disease,hypertension,surgery or any drug intake.HIV status is negative.There is no family history of kidney disease. He also gives history of several colds and sinus infections over the past year. What is the reason for this patient to have frequent respiratory infections?

options.label: A
options.text: The function of the neutrophils is decreased.

options.label: C
options.text: Antibodies are not made when the albumin level is low.

questions.correct_answer: B. IgG is lost in urine.

questions.text: A 60 year old male presented with 6 months h/o gradually progressing swelling first involving the face,now its all over the body.He has gained 15 kg in last 6 months.There is history of passing frothy urine.He gives history of osteoarthritis of knees.There is no h/o diabetes,hypertension,heart disease,HIV, and hepatitis.He doesn’t smoke or take alcohol.On urine analysis proteins are 4+,you are suspecting nephrotic syndrome. Which of these medications should you ask the patient about having used?

A 40 year old male diagnosed as a case of membranous glomerulopathy in view of massive proteinuria and kidney biopsy findings. He was started on immunosuppressive therapy. The patient comes back in 2 weeks with increasing swelling in legs. The swelling is worse in one leg than the other. Lower extremity Doppler ultrasound shows a deep venous thrombosis (DVT). The patient is started on enoxaparin and warfarin. His urine protein-to-creatinine ratio is 7:1. What is the mechanism of DVT in nephrotic syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: Urine loss of clotting factors (II, VII, IX, X).

options.label: C
options.text: Urine loss of protein C, S, and antithrombin.

options.label: D
options.text: Low albumin level leading to stasis.

questions.correct_answer: C. Urine loss of protein C, S, and antithrombin.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a history of hypertension and diabetes who has had renal insufficiency for several years now comes to the OPD for evaluation of his kidneys. The patient is obese and has had difficulty controlling both his diabetes and high BP. He is adherent to diet and tries to exercise. Present Medications: Lisinopril, amlodipine, Sitagliptin, Gliclazide. On examination- Extremities: mild edema present, Chest: clear bilaterally, Cardiovascular: S4 gallop; no murmurs. BP: 150/96 mm Hg; Pulse: 64 beats/minute; serum creatinine 4 mg/dL; potassium 4.9 mEq/L; bicarbonate 22 mEq/L: urine dipstix- protein 2+,What will you do next.

options.label: A
options.text: Observation with serial kidney function tests

options.label: B
options.text: Increase anti Diabetes and antihypertensive drugs

questions.correct_answer: B. Increase anti Diabetes and antihypertensive drugs

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with hypertension and chronic kidney disease for 20 years. He complaints of fatigue, weight loss, breathlessness on exertion and increasing sleepiness for last 1 month. On examination pallor +, extremity edema +, flapping tremors+, lungs-mild basal crepts, cardiovascular system- pericardial friction rub +. Lab results-Hb-8.0 g/dl,serum creatinine 7.0 mg/dl, BUN 150 mg/dl, serum K 7.0 mmol/L,pH-7.32,serum HCO3- 21 mmol/L,paCO2- 37 mmHg. You decided to plan for dialysis in the patient. Which of the patient’s manifestation not an indication for dialysis?

A 60-year-old man with lung cancer diagnosed several weeks ago is admitted to the emergency department. He has been undergoing a staging evaluation and has not started therapy. He is brought in by his wife because he has been increasingly confused over the past 2 days. He had been a tobacco smoker for 30 years, quit 5 years ago. On examination BP:112/76 mm Hg; Pulse: 100/minute; Neurological: lethargic, confused, examination incomplete secondary to inability to follow commands ,Extremities: no edema, no dehydration ,Cardiovascular: normal, Abdomen: normal. Which of these will not be a cause of confusion in the patient?

In continuation with previous clinical vignette, Lab tests were done which revealed serum sodium 112 mEq/L; BUN 8 mg/dL; creatinine 0.7 mg/dL, uric acid 2.0 mg/dl(low), Urine sodium 64 mEq/L (high), Urine osmolarity 480 mOsm/kg Oximeter: 97% on room air, Calcium: 9.2 mg/dL. LFT-normal. Head CT: no metastases. What is the most likely cause of this presentation.

options.label: B
options.text: Nephrotic syndrome due to paraneoplastic syndrome

options.label: D
options.text: Syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone (SIADH)

questions.correct_answer: D. Syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone (SIADH)

questions.text: The patient in previous question was started on hypertonic saline. After 24 hours serum sodium reaches 132 mmol/L. Remember the initial serum sodium was 112 mmol/L. The patient seems to improve in sensorium. Next day he was discharged on Tolvaptan and to follow up for cancer management. But 4 days later patient c/o of weakness of all 4 limbs, difficulty in articulation and difficulty in swallowing. What must have caused these neurological symptoms of the patient.

A 25-year-old man was brought to ED after head trauma from a motorcycle accident. The initial head CT was normal. He was visibly intoxicated from alcohol. On examination-patient dehydrated, BP: 102/72 mm Hg; Pulse- 104 /minute; Neurological: lethargic, confused, and unable to name the date or the place where he is right now; focal neurological signs cannot be assessed because of patient confusion Heart, Lungs, Abdomen: normal. Head CT: no bleeding, sodium 165 mEq/L (normal 135-145 mEq/L); creatinine 1.8 mg/dl, Oximeter: normal, Liver function: normal, Urine osmolarity: 80 mOsm/kg. Nurses report two urinations over the next 2 hours with 400 mL in each one. What is the likely cause of this presentation

options.label: D
options.text: Non renal cause of dehydration induced hypernatremia

questions.text: In continuation of previous clinical vignette, a diagnosis of central diabetes insipidus was made. You decide to start patient IV fluids. What is the fluid deficit in this patient assuming patient body weight as 70 kg.

A 25 year old female diagnosed a case of sarcoidosis 1 year back is presenting with c/o of polyuria.Lab results shows urine osmolality 120 mosm/Kg,urine volume 5 L/d.After Water deprivation test urine osmolality remains low.You are suspecting central diabetes insipidus. You gave vasopressin.After vasopressin administration, which values are consistent with central diabetes insipidus (CDI)?

A 32-year-old woman admitted for combination chemotherapy for non-Hodgkin lymphoma is in the hospital the night after the administration of the medications. She had IV fluids started the morning of the chemotherapy. She received cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin (Adriamycin), vincristine, and prednisone. She is now feeling severe muscle weakness. On examination- BP:110/70 mm Hg; Pulse- 80 /minute; Temperature- 100°F; CVS/repiratory /Neurological: normal, Musculoskeletal: decreased motor strength in all four extremities. Lab Report:BUN-24 mg/dl,serum creatinine1.9 mg/dl, serum Potassium 6.6 mEq/dL, serum uric acid 10.4 mg/dl,serum phosphate- 7.0 mg/dl(elevated), Urine Analysis: normal. what is the most likely diagnosis

options.label: C
options.text: Chemotherapy induced intrinsic acute renal failure

questions.text: In continuation of previous clinical vignette, patient was started on IV fluids, IV calcium gluconate, insulin (for hyperkalemia) and allopurinol. Several hours later, the potassium level has been normalized and the muscle weakness has resolved. Repeat chemistry shows the creatinine level rises from 0.8 to 1.5 mg/dL. Uric acid is still high. Six hours later, despite fluids and allopurinol, the creatinine goes to 1.7 mg/dL.What will be next line of treatment

A 48-year-old man with acquired immunodeficiency syndrome is admitted to the hospital 1 week history of fever, headache, and stiff neck. The head CT was normal. He is not adherent to his antiretroviral therapy. His CD4 count is 50 cells/mm3.On examination- BP:150/90 mm Hg; Pulse rate: 100 /minute; Temperature: 102°F, photophobia and nuchal rigidity are present; fully alert; no focal findings detected. Lab Report: Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF): WBCs- 1200 /mm3, 94% lymphocytes, Opening pressure elevated, Gram stain negative, Protein elevated. A provisional diagnosis of cryptococcus meningitis was made. What is the best initial therapy in this patient?

In continuation with previous case, amphotericin and antiretroviral drugs are started. The cryptococcal antigen comes back the next day markedly elevated. After 5 days, the chemistry test results are: Potassium 3.0 mEq/L (low), Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL(high), Serum bicarbonate 16 mEq/L (normal 22-26 mEq/L), Sodium 140 mEq/L, Chloride 114 mEq/L (elevated). What causes this change in laboratory results?

A 20-year-old homeless male brought to emergency by nearby people with altered sensorium. No other detailed history available. On examination-patient is disoriented,repiratory,cardiovascular and abdomen-normal. On Lab tests Serum Na 145 mmol/L, Chloride 115 mmol/L, HCO3-20 mmol/L, pH- 7.30, PaCO2- 36 mmHg. CT head is normal.A diagnosis of non-anion gap metabolic acidosis is made.You are suspecting diarrhea and renal tubular acidosis in differential diagnosis.Which test can be used to distinguish diarrhea and Renal tubular acidosis as the cause of normal anion gap metabolic acidosis?

A 60-year-old male patient developed severe COVID pneumonia with low oxygen saturation. He was admitted in ICU and started on IV steroids, low molecular weight heparin and oxygen support. After 10 days he was discharged as oxygen saturation improved. One week later he developed headache, pain with redness in eyes and blackish discharge from nose. CT scan and KOH stain revealed suspected rhino-orbital Mucormycosis. He was started on amphotericin. Which of the following can be the urinary findings in the patient?

A 15 year old boy was brought to OPD by parents with c/o fatigue and growth retardation.On examination patient is slightly dehydrated,BP-100/60.Lab tests- serum creatinine 1.0 mg/dl,serum K-2.3 mmol/L,serum Na-136 mmol/L,pH-7.48,serum HCO3-28 mmol/L, urine calcium low.Based on these manifestations what is the most likely diagnostic possibility

A 38-year-old man is referred with a history of polydipsia and polyuria passing over 3 L of urine in 24 hours. He undergoes a water deprivation test followed by desmopressin test, which shows the following results:

A 24-year-old woman is dipstick positive for blood in her urine. This is repeated twice between menstrual periods and remains positive. Microscopic evaluation reveals RBCs, some of which are deformed and some in the form of casts. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the hematuria?

A 32-year-old man has trace proteinuria on dipstick urinalysis. A 24-hour urine collection reveals 80 mg/day of protein excretion in the urine. You council the patient regarding these findings. Which of the following statements concerning this degree of proteinuria is correct?

options.label: B
options.text: This degree of proteinuria has no prognostic values

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents with a large myocardial infarction and undergoes primary coronary angiography and stenting. Two days later he develops a low-grade fever. investigations reveal: urinalysis: eosinophilic cast; haemoglobin 14 g/L; with eosinophilia. What is the most likely cause of his acute kidney injury?

It is hospital day 5 for a 65-year-old patient with prerenal azotemia secondary to dehydration. His creatinine was initially 3.6 mg/dL on admission, but it has improved today to 2.1 mg/dL. He complains of mild lower back pain, and you prescribe naproxen. After 2 days his creatinine again increased to 3.5 mg/dl. By what mechanism might this drug further impair his renal function?

A 50-year-old woman presents with acute kidney injury after an acute illness manifested by myalgia, diarrhea and vomiting. Her BP is 84/50 mmHg and she has dry mucous membranes. Her renal function improves rapidly with intravenous fluids. You did urine analysis and blood tests. Which one of the following findings are likely to be present?
questions.correct_answer: D. Low (< 1%) fractional excretion of sodium

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to the emergency room after a motor vehicle accident in which she sustained a crush injury and is found to have acute kidney injury 3 days after admission to the hospital. Laboratory data reveal creatinine 3 mg/dL, calcium 6.5 mg/dL, and phosphorus 6 mg/dL. Creatine kinase is found to be 10,000 U/L. What is the most appropriate next line treatment?

A 17-year-old male falls ill with vomiting and bloody diarrhoea. 3 days later he notices that his urinary output has declined. His temperature is 38.2°C, he has bilateral ankle oedema, but no other clinical signs. The following investigation results are obtained: urea 108 mg/dL; creatinine 6 mg/dL; haemoglobin 6.4 g/dL; platelet count 36000/mm3; blood film shows schistocytes; stool cultures negative for Escherichia coli O157. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 57-year-old man with a history of diabetes mellitus underwent cardiac catheterization for acute myocardial infarction. He is subsequently diagnosed with acute kidney injury related to iodinated contrast. All of the following statements are true regarding his acute kidney injury EXCEPT:

options.label: B
options.text: His creatinine is likely to peak within 3–5 days.

options.label: C
options.text: His diabetes mellitus predisposed him to develop contrast nephropathy.

options.label: D
options.text: White blood cell casts are likely on microscopic examination of urinary sediment.

questions.correct_answer: D. White blood cell casts are likely on microscopic examination of urinary sediment.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman with a history of asthma and gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and chronic cough presents with a fever, rash, and a newly noted eosinophilia, associated with acute kidney injury. Urinalysis is remarkable for cellular casts. She has been on inhaled steroids for treatment of her asthma and was recently initiated on treatment for GERD in the setting of a persistent cough. What is the likely cause of the patient’s acute kidney injury?

A 63-year-old woman with chronic kidney disease is maintained on daily peritoneal dialysis. Her past medical history is notable for hypertension and atrial fibrillation. Her medications include losartan and warfarin. Two days ago, she noticed a small painful nodule on her abdomen that has progressed to involve skin necrosis and ulceration of the abdominal wall.

options.label: A
options.text: Oral calcium supplement may be a risk factor

options.label: B
options.text: This condition is due to calciphylaxis

options.label: C
options.text: Warfarin is a risk factor for development of the lesion

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with a history of stage 4 chronic kidney disease, hypertension, stroke, and recently diagnosed lung cancer presents to the clinic for evaluation of asymptomatic anemia. Hemoglobin is 10.5 g/dL. Iron stores are normal. Vitamin B12 and folate levels are found to be normal. What is the next step?

options.label: B
options.text: Transfuse packed red blood cells and start an erythropoietin-stimulating agent.

options.label: D
options.text: Counsel the patient on vascular access for dialysis

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with newly diagnosed Hodgkin lymphoma associated with bilateral lower extremity edema. Laboratory workup reveals 10 g of proteinuria on a 24-hour urine collection. Which of the following pathologic entities most likely explains the presence of proteinuria in this patient?

A 47-year-old man with recently diagnosed HIV infection in the setting of esophageal candidiasis is referred for evaluation of bilateral lower extremity edema associated with a serum creatinine of 2 mg/dL and 3+ albumin by urine dipstick. A 24-hour urine collection reveals 6 g of proteinuria. Testing for hepatitis B and C is negative. After confirming the suspected diagnosis of HIV associated nephropathy without interstitial inflammation on kidney biopsy, which of the following treatment options should be pursued in addition to an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor?

A 50-year-old obese female with a 5-year history of mild hypertension controlled by a thiazide diuretic is being evaluated because proteinuria was noted on a urine dipstick during her routine yearly medical visit. Physical examination weight of 91 kg, blood pressure of 130/80 mmHg, elevated and pedal edema. Laboratory values are as follows: Serum creatinine: 1.2 mg/dL BUN: 18 mg/dL Urinalysis: protein 3+ Urine protein excretion: 5.9 g/d A renal biopsy demonstrates that 60% of the glomeruli, mostly in the corticomedullary junction, have segmental scarring by light microscopy, with the remainder of the glomeruli appearing unremarkable. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 24-year-old woman presents with nausea, vomiting, anorexia, and gross hematuria. She had a sore throat 2 weeks ago that resolved on its own. On examination, her blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg, pulse 90/min, JVP is 7 cm, heart sounds are normal, there is 1+ pedal edema, and the lungs are clear. She has a renal biopsy. Which of the following electron microscopy findings on the renal biopsy is most likely?

options.label: A
options.text: Hypercellularity of mesangial and endothelial cells

questions.text: A previously healthy 17-year-old male presents with a 2- to 3-week history of arthralgia and more recently has developed a skin rash on the lower legs. Just prior to admission to hospital he developed abdominal discomfort with blood-stained stool. On examination, he has rash over his limbs. Initial investigations reveal: Anti GBM ab negative, Platelet counts elevated, urinalysis: blood 3+; What is the most likely diagnosis?

An 18-year-old man presents 3 days after an upper respiratory tract infection, with rise in creatinine from 0.9 to 1.6 mg/dL. The patient’s urinalysis reveals 2+ blood and 2+ protein. C3 and C4 are normal. ANCA and anti-GBM ab are negative. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 28-year-old woman presents with a recent episode of hemoptysis, frequent nose bleeds, and decreased urine output. A nasal mucosa ulcer was seen on inspection. Her urinalysis is positive for protein 2+ and red cells with casts. The CXR shows two cavitary lesions and her serology is positive for ANCA. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 21-year-old male college student is evaluated for profound fatigue that has been present for several years but has recently become debilitating. He also reports several foot spasms and cramps and occasionally sustained muscle contractions that are uncontrollable. He is otherwise healthy, takes no medications, and denies tobacco or alcohol use. On examination, he is well developed with normal vital signs including blood pressure. The remainder of the examination is normal. Laboratory evaluation shows a serum sodium of 134 mEq/L, potassium of 2.8 mEq/L, and bicarbonate of 30 mmol/L. Urine screen for diuretics is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A patient with a history of Sjogren syndrome has the following laboratory findings: plasma sodium 139 mEq/L, chloride 112 mEq/L, bicarbonate 15 mEq/L, and potassium 3.0 mEq/L. Urine studies show a pH of 6.0, sodium of 15 mEq/L, potassium of 10 mEq/L, and chloride of 12 mEq/L. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 25-year-old man presents to clinic with 3 weeks of extreme fatigue, worsening lower extremity edema, and frothy urine. He takes no medications. On physical examination, he is afebrile, blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg, heart rate is 70 beats per minute, and there is 2+ lower extremity pitting edema to the knees. Laboratory data show hemoglobin, 12.0 g/dL, creatinine, 1.2 mg/dL, albumin, 3.0 g/dL, lowdensity-lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol, 180 mg/dL, and proteinuria of 8 g/24 hours. Urine sediment review reveals four or five dysmorphic red blood cells per high power field, with no evidence of cellular casts or crystals. A kidney biopsy is performed, which reveals normal appearing glomeruli by light microscopy, no immunoglobulin or complement positivity by immunofluorescence microscopy, and podocyte foot process effacement accompanied by microvillous transformation by electron microscopy consistent with minimal change glomerulopathy. Of note, no focal areas of interstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy are apparent. Which of the following is the most appropriate next treatment step for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Supportive care with ACE inhibitor and an LDL-lowering agent

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is seen in the emergency department and admitted to the hospital with anasarca. He takes venlafaxine for depression. On physical examination, he is afebrile, blood pressure is 170/100 mm Hg, heart rate is 60 beats per minute, and there is 3+ lower extremity pitting edema that extends to the low back. Laboratory data show hemoglobin, 10.0 g/dL, creatinine, 1.5 mg/dL (baseline unknown), albumin, 1.5 g/ dL, and proteinuria, 12 g/24 hours. Urine sediment review reveals numerous lipid droplets and fatty casts, with no evidence of dysmorphic red blood cells, cellular casts, or crystals. A kidney biopsy is performed, which reveals focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS). Which of the following is the clinically aggressive variant of FSGS?

A 20-year-old woman presents to clinic with three episodes of macroscopic hematuria that have occurred over the past 6 months around the time of recurrent upper respiratory tract infections. The physical examination is unremarkable except for a blood pressure of 140/90 mm Hg. Laboratory data show hemoglobin, 11.0 g/ dL, creatinine, 0.9 mg/dL (unchanged from baseline), and proteinuria of 3 g/24 hours. A kidney biopsy is performed, which reveals diffuse mesangio-proliferative glomerulonephritis and mild endocapillary hypercellularity consistent with IgA nephropathy and associated mild interstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy. The patient is started on lisinopril, which is up titrated over 6 months to a maximally tolerated dose; however, proteinuria of 3 g/24 hours persists. Which of the following is the most appropriate next treatment step for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Fish oil containing omega-3 fatty acids plus tonsillectomy

questions.text: A 71-year-old man with underlying stage 3 chronic kidney disease (estimated glomerular filtration rate = 47 mL/min per 1.73 m2 ) is hospitalized for upper arm cellulitis and is treated with intravenous piperacillin– tazobactam. After 9 days of therapy, serum creatinine concentration rises abruptly from baseline 1.8 mg/dL to 3.3 mg/dL. Despite intravenous fluids, kidney function continues to decline over the next 3 days. Complete blood cell count is within normal limits with white blood cells (WBCs) 9.0 and eosinophils 4%. Electrolytes are normal. Urinalysis reveals 1+ protein, 1+ blood, and 1+ leukocyte esterase. Urine sediment reveals 10–15 WBCs/high-power field (HPF), 3–5 red blood cells/HPF, and 1–2 WBC casts/ low-power field. Urine eosinophils are >1% on Hansel stain and urine culture is negative. Renal ultrasound shows bilateral 15-cm kidneys with increased echogenicity and no hydronephrosis. Which of the following will secure a diagnosis of acute tubulointerstitial nephritis as the cause of acute kidney injury in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Large, echogenic kidneys on renal ultrasound

options.label: D
options.text: Kidney biopsy showing inflammatory interstitial infiltrate is required

questions.correct_answer: D. Kidney biopsy showing inflammatory interstitial infiltrate is required

questions.text: A 79-year-old female patient is diagnosed with HFrEF as a consequence of diffuse coronary artery disease. According to heart failure guidelines, she is started on ACE inhibitor therapy (enalapril 2.5 mg bid, up-titrated to 5 mg bid after 2 weeks). At the next follow-up visit, the patient feels better but describes occasional postural hypotension, and her serum creatinine level has risen by to 1.3 mg/dL (baseline was 1.1 mg/dl). Blood pressure is now 108/60 mm Hg. The next step with regard to her ACE inhibitor therapy is

options.label: A
options.text: Up titrate ACE inhibitor therapy further

options.label: D
options.text: Continue ACE inhibitor at the same dose

questions.correct_answer: D. Continue ACE inhibitor at the same dose

questions.text: A 73-year-old man is identified as having a 70% stenosis of his right renal artery during CT angiography for abdominal pain. The left renal artery was normal. He has two-vessel coronary disease, for which stents were placed a month earlier. His cardiologist recommends that he undergo renal artery stenting after six months of clopidogrel therapy. He has hypertension for 15 years and now feels well. His current medications include an ACE inhibitor, a beta-blocker, an alpha-blocker, a diuretic, clopidogrel, and aspirin. BP: 146/74 mm Hg, Pulse: 65/min, Chest- Clear; No edema, Lab reports: CBC normal, Serum creatinine 1.4 mg/dL (eGFR: 49 mL/min/1.73 m2 ), sodium 140 mEq/L, potassium 4.6 mEq/L. Which of the following most accurately describes the likely results of renal artery stenting for this individual?

A 66-year-old male presented to the renal clinic for 6-month follow-up of his known diabetic nephropathy. The trajectory of renal function decline with regard to his estimated GFR has been 2–4 mL/min/1.73 m2 over the past 4 years. He has had a slowly rising urine albumin to-creatinine ratio (uACR) and his most recent uACR was 150 mg/g. Now he presents with 2-month history of fatigue, anorexia, and unintentional weight loss of 5–6 kg. Physical examination revealed pulse rate of 80 beats/min and blood pressure of 140/80 mm Hg, oxygen saturation 95% on room air, clear chest, 1+ pedal edema, and mild pallor. Laboratory investigations for this clinical visit are as follows: Hemoglobin- 10.3 g/dL, serum creatinine 4 mg/dl, eGFR 20 mL/min/1.73 m2 , K 5.7 mmol/L, Na 137 mmol/L, HCO3- 20 mmol/L, and serum albumin 3.2 g/dL. Urinalysis showed 2+ protein and 3+ red blood cells. Urine microscopy revealed a few red cell casts. Which of these is the most appropriate response with regard to this man’s condition?

options.label: A
options.text: This is most likely a laboratory error; repeat blood work should be organized.

options.label: B
options.text: He has lost a significant amount of weight in the recent past, which has resulted in a rise in creatinine.

options.label: C
options.text: He has evidence of significant acute kidney injury and needs further investigation.

options.label: D
options.text: This is the natural progression of his underlying diabetic nephropathy.

questions.correct_answer: C. He has evidence of significant acute kidney injury and needs further investigation.

questions.text: A 73-year-old woman was referred to the clinic for evaluation of worsening renal function and anemia. Review of her laboratory tests showed hemoglobin-8.0 g/dL, serum creatinine-2.4 mg/dl, K 4.6 mmol/L, Na 132 mmol/L, calcium 2.7 mmol/L(elevated). Her serum protein electrophoresis showed a monoclonal spike in the gamma region. A diagnosis of multiple myeloma is suspected. An office urine dipstick shows 1+ protein, no red cells, no leukocytes, or glucose. Which of the following statements is true with regard to the urine dipstick result?

options.label: A
options.text: The urine dipstick reliably detects albumin but not other proteins such as monoclonal proteins which cause cast nephropathy.

options.label: B
options.text: The urine dipstick is a sensitive marker for tubular and overflow proteinuria.

options.label: C
options.text: A positive result from a semiquantitative test, such as a urinary dipstick test, should prompt further evaluation with a quantitative test.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man presents to the emergency room with a large-volume upper gastrointestinal bleed. Medical history is significant for hypertension and a recent myocardial infarction for which he required percutaneous coronary intervention to the left anterior descending artery. His medications include aspirin, clopidogrel, atorvastatin, ramipril, and atenolol. His blood pressure on arrival was 90/60 mm Hg and he was resuscitated with intravenous fluids and packed red blood cells. He is awaiting a gastroscopy. Laboratory investigations showed hemoglobin-7.5 g%, normal international normalized ratio and partial thromboplastin time, sodium 135 mmol/L, potassium 3.8 mmol/L, urea 100 mg/dl, creatinine 1.35 mg/dl and estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) 50 mL/min/1.73 m2 . Which of the following holds true with regard to his renal function tests?

options.label: A
options.text: This patient has intrinsic acute kidney injury as evidenced by the rise in urea.

options.label: B
options.text: This patient has intrinsic acute kidney injury as evidenced by the decline in eGFR.

options.label: C
options.text: Urea is a poor marker of filtration as in this case it is influenced by upper GI bleeding.

options.label: D
options.text: Creatinine is an ideal filtration marker as it is freely filtered but not secreted from the renal tubules.

questions.correct_answer: C. Urea is a poor marker of filtration as in this case it is influenced by upper GI bleeding.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman with ESRD on hemodialysis is evaluated for painful nodules on the abdomen which have been present for the past month. Medications include warfarin, metoprolol, atorvastatin, renal vitamin, calcium acetate. She is receiving calciferol and darbopoietin with dialysis. Physical examination reveals an overweight female with several hard, subcutaneous nodules approximately 1 cm in diameter in the lower abdomen; there is one open wound 1.5 cm in diameter with surrounding erythema. Laboratory studies reveal the following results: calcium 9.7 mg/dL; phosphate 6.0 mg/dL; PTH 550 pg/ mL. She undergoes a punch biopsy of the wound which shows findings consistent with calcific uremic arteriolopathy. Which of the following therapeutic approaches would you recommend?

A 60-year-old female patient 6 months post kidney transplant is evaluated in routine follow-up. Physical exam is unremarkable. Laboratory studies reveal the following: creatinine 1.0 g/dL, calcium 10.8 mg/dL; phosphate 2.8 mg/dL; PTH 150 pg/mL. Which of the following statements about her condition is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Hyperparathyroidism is uncommon following a successful kidney transplant

options.label: B
options.text: She should be referred to an endocrine surgeon for parathyroidectomy

options.label: C
options.text: Cinacalcet may offer effective therapy for her hyperparathyroidism

options.label: D
options.text: Post-transplant hypercalcemia is not associated with increased mortality or graft loss

questions.correct_answer: C. Cinacalcet may offer effective therapy for her hyperparathyroidism

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with intermittent diarrhea of 6 months’ duration is referred to you for evaluation of bone pain. Previous evaluation has shown the presence of celiac disease. The following tests are available for evaluation of her symptoms. Hemoglobin 10.5 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume 105 fL, serum folate 2.5 µg/L, serum sodium 135 mEq/L, potassium 3.7 mEq/L, chloride 105 mEq/L, bicarbonate 22 mEq/L, creatinine 0.9 mg/dL, blood urea nitrogen 12 mg/dL, total serum calcium 8.5 mg/dL, ionized calcium 4.0 mg/ dL, phosphorus 2.5 mg/dL, alkaline phosphatase 200 U/L, parathyroid hormone 80 pg/mL and 25-hydroxyvitamin D 10 ng/ mL. Urinalysis is normal. Urine microscopy is normal. Bone densitometry shows osteopenia. A 24-hour urine sample is collected for measurement of calcium, phosphorus, and creatinine. In regard to her urinary analytes, one will anticipate that
questions.correct_answer: A. 24-hour urine calcium will be low.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female is referred to you for evaluation of bone pain. She was completely well 2 years ago when she started developing intermittent aches and pains. Family history is non contributory. Laboratory values show the following: hemoglobin 12.8 g/ dL, MCV 85 fL, leukocyte and platelet count. Serum sodium, potassium, chloride, and bicarbonate are normal. Serum calcium is 9.2 mg/dL, phosphorus 2.0 mg/dL, alkaline phosphatase 350 U/L, 25-hydroxyvitamin D 22 ng/mL, and PTH 100 pg/mL. What is the likely cause?

A 62-year-old male is on chronic hemodialysis because of kidney failure attributed to type 2 diabetes. Blood pressure is 150/82 mm Hg, serum creatinine 3.9 mg/dl, Hb is 11.5 g/dL, and HbA1c is 9.5%. He is not being treated with any hypoglycaemic medicines. The patient takes a statin and erythropoietin. He has a good nutritional status. Which of the following statements is true?

options.label: A
options.text: The hyperglycemia should not be treated because HbA1c is not a reliable indicator of glucose in the setting of kidney failure, and the patient is otherwise in good condition.

options.label: B
options.text: The use of erythropoietin and the reduced RBC lifespan seen in kidney failure causes HbA1c to overestimate glucose.

options.label: C
options.text: Treatment with insulin should be considered to achieve a reduction in HbA1c and reduce mortality risk.

questions.correct_answer: C. Treatment with insulin should be considered to achieve a reduction in HbA1c and reduce mortality risk.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female who is referred to you because her eGFR was 22 ml/min/1.73 m2 and her fasting plasma glucose concentration was 382 mg/dL. She has a BMI of 44 kg/m2. She reports no other health issues except that she has some occasional numbness and tingling in her feet. Her mother had type 2 diabetes. On physical examination, you observe acanthosis nigricans, small exudates on the retina of both eyes and a dot hemorrhages in her right eye. Ankle and knee reflexes are absent and her spot urine contains 2800 mg albumin per gram creatinine. She has no ketones in her urine. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Type 1 diabetes and stage 4 diabetes kidney disease.

options.label: B
options.text: Type 2 diabetes and stage 4 diabetes kidney disease.

options.label: C
options.text: Type 1 diabetes and stage 5 diabetes kidney disease.

options.label: D
options.text: Type 2 diabetes and stage 5 diabetes kidney disease.

questions.correct_answer: B. Type 2 diabetes and stage 4 diabetes kidney disease.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male with a 15 years history of type 1 diabetes presented in OPD. His A1C is 7% and his blood pressure is 130/80. You screen for diabetes kidney disease and find albuminuria and eGFR as 50 ml/min/1.73 m2. His complement is normal. A renal ultrasound demonstrates a complex mass that is confirmed by biopsy to be a renal cell carcinoma. When the patient undergoes nephrectomy, the pathologist reports thickening of the glomerular basement membrane in the nontumoral portion of the parenchyma and no deposits. Immunofluorescence is negative. The likely diagnosis is:

A 48-year-old female comes to you with uncontrolled type 1 diabetes, heart failure and new onset of severe albuminuria despite maximal dose of ramipril. She does not have diabetic retinopathy. Her urinary sediment is unremarkable and her urine albumin creatinine ratio is 1600 mg/g. She has normocytic anemia and a normal platelet count. Her creatinine is 1.3 mg/dL. Which test is most likely to reveal the appropriate diagnosis?

A 35-year-old male with type 1 diabetes, hypertension and established CKD comes to OPD for routine check-up. He is on insulin, amlodipine and losartan. BP is 120/80 mmHg.Hba1c is 6.9 %, serum creatinine 2.0 mg/dl and serum uric acid 9.2 mg/dl. His urinary sediment is unremarkable and his urine ACR(albumin creatinine ratio) is 400 mg/g. Which of the following are true about his management

options.label: B
options.text: Stop amlodipine as it increases serum uric acid
